head.title: 2-Part Fannie Mae Offering Of Debentures Priced at Par

hedline.hl1: 2-Part Fannie Mae Offering Of Debentures Priced at Par

block.p: LEAD: A two-part financing by the Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, totaling $1.4 billion and consisting of an equal amount of five-year and 10-year debentures, was priced at par yesterday through various securities dealers.

LEAD: A two-part financing by the Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, totaling $1.4 billion and consisting of an equal amount of five-year and 10-year debentures, was priced at par yesterday through various securities dealers.

A two-part financing by the Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, totaling $1.4 billion and consisting of an equal amount of five-year and 10-year debentures, was priced at par yesterday through various securities dealers.
The five-year debentures due March 10, 1995, were given an 8.85 percent coupon and priced to yield about 27 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

Fannie Mae said the 10-year debentures due March 10, 2000, were different from the five-year issue, in that the debentures were callable at its option in whole or in part on March 10, 1993 and from time to time thereafter.
Determing the price at redemption would be based on a formula tied to the principal amount redeemed and the coupon rate on the issue, said Fannie Mae, with the initial redemption price at 104.65.
The 10-year debentures were priced to yield about 68.5 basis points more than Treasuries.
